reviewText:
Town of Salem is presented somewhat in the style of an animated board game, pitting fifteen people against each other in a clever roleplay battle of wit, perception, strategy, and deception.

A quick recount of a fun session I played.
In a recent game, I was the serial killer. That means I can kill at night and can not be killed. All I have to do is keep killing people, keep deceiving them, and not leave any clues for them to suspect me. I won this specific game, because there was a player named Snoop Dogg and every time I killed someone, I would leave a death note" with a vague dog-related reference on the victim - even some as obtuse as "Bow down before the Lion". This made people increasingly suspicious that this other player was the serial killer

reviewText:
A tough review to write.

This is a free game. You can play it in your browser at any time. What I hope is that the devs will take this steam money and 1. improve the interface. 2. fix the bugs. and 3. fix the ♥♥♥♥ing interface bugs.

So, let me count the problems with this game:
1. Inteface bugs. Menus will/may get stuck on your screen, preventing you from a proper play.
2. Mafia is possible OP? maybe? (Update: I have lost once as Godfather out of countless games. I am either ♥♥♥♥ing incredible at that role, or it really is OP)
3. Mediums ♥♥♥♥ing suck.: Clarification: The medium can actually be really helpfull. The problem lies with the fact that people always leave as soon as they die, rendering the medium useless.
4. No way to exit a game, back to the lobby, without closing.
5. As with any MP game, there are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and obnoxious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
6. quitters.
7. You should not be able to pick a different name at the beginning of each round. There is no way to keep track of the trolls and the a55holes.

Now let me count the ways I love thee:
1. This game is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing addicting. I am seriously considering ripping it off and creating the same game under a different title. With a better UI,
2. So much fun. No matter your role, you will have such a good time just watching the absolute paranoia, the accusations, the threats, and the mediums giving up imediately
3. I can't stress enough how ♥♥♥♥ing funny this game can be. It is the players that make it so. You never know who is using reverse psychology, or reverse reverse phsycology. This is a thinking man's game, but at the same time, a non-thinkers game. YOU CAN NOT KNOW!

Sure, there are more gripes on my list than compliments, but the gravity is not the same. I would absolutely recommend this game to any friend with a head on his or her shoulders. It was given to me as a gift on the same night I spent over $200 on Steam games, and I have put more than double the time into it. As I said before, it is a free browser game, but your $5 helps the devs to improve it. And I hope they do. I will continue to consider completely ripping this game off, and creating my own.I could make a fortune. Absolute genius of a game.

Tips for making the game better for everyone playing, including yourself:

1. If you are bored and trolling, play CoD.
2. Fill out your will. Any info or observations can be very helpful to your fellow townies. especially in roles like escort, jailor and invest.
3. Leave the racism at gradeschool. No one want to hear it, no one thinks it's funny.
4. Don't spam the chat. See Tip# 3. It's also against the rules.
5. Don't be an obvious jester. It's immediately obvious and annoying.
6. Hate language is childish and ignorant. Grow up.
7. Please, for the love of god, you do not need to declare your depraved sexual status in your name.
8. If you are mafia/sk, kill the most obnoxious player first night.

reviewText:
First off, as you can tell by the number of hours that I put in the game, Town of Salem is a game that I very much enjoyed playing, although it was mostly first 40 hours. Once past those 40 hours, the scroll update fell upon Town of salem.

I would have recommended the game without a doubt before the update that introduced the scrolls.

Town of Salem is a fun game(similar to the Werewolf game), that requires you to be deceitful and think logically in order to win. You have to think strategically your every move, choose who to trust carefully. You get a role at the start of each game, with its own objectives and skills.

Most roles are fun and require a unique way of playing it. The townies are the most numerous and have to work together, the mafia must also work together, but in secret and most of the neutrals have their own agenda.

The two main game types allow for some very fun games.

The classic game type forces you to play with a given set of roles that make for a balanced game.
The custom game type let the host decide what the roles are going to be, which adds a lot of replayability and diversity to the game.

If you like the Werewolf type of game, I think you'd like town of Salem.

However, I cannot recommend Town of Salem as of right now.

Since the scrolls were introduced, the game is a lot more frustrating.

The scrolls are in-game items that allow you to boost your chances of getting a specific role.
For instance, I can boost my chances of getting the role Serial killer" from 7%(the default value) to 52%.

This will logically decrease the odds for all the other players

reviewText:
I enjoy Town of Salem and I've spent a great deal of time playing it. I'll certainly play it some more. There are a lot of interesting aspects to it, more so than your average social deduction game. As for whether or not you should play it, I think it's high quality and a load of fun, but I'm not going to put an enormous amount of effort into convincing you this...

I started playing it because some friends got me into it. You can set up lobbies ingame and invite people - as long as you aren't revealing info in a skype call that wouldn't automatically be known to everyone anyway, it's probably the best experience. Social deduction games always have a bit more flair to them when you know who you're playing with (without knowing if they're for you or against you)

http://blankmediagames.com/TownOfSalem/

I fully recommend playing this game on your web browser, as the free website version and the steam version are nearly identical. With all of that being said, I bought the steam edition several months ago because I was sick of dealing with inevitable web browser performance issues and such - they even offer some coins to spend on skins or a pet or something.

Unfortunately, I regret spending money on the steam version, as I did not get much out of it (there really are like no benefits to this over playing in a web browser...) and the money also clearly didn't go anywhere worthwhile. As of right now, Blank Media Games has made a hella big profit off of their card game Kickstarter:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/blankmediagames/town-of-salem-the-card-game

I don't imagine this game translating very well to a tabletop setting - a lot of the anonymity and role actions seem hard to emulate outside of a videogame, and I don't see why you wouldn't just gather some friends and play it like you would a LAN party game. That being said, at first it seemed promising, so I almost got the set. But the Kickstarter is starting to make it clear that the devs have a much different idea than I do concerning how us players should spend our money. The initial card game goal was $10,000. Despite having already reached $250,000 - BMG has still set up stretch goals after another whopping $100,000. This new stretch goal, if met, would add two new roles to the card game. These roles do not seem optimized or very originally thought up. In the ~9 months that I have been playing Town of Salem now, the videogame itself has only gotten two roles, the vampire and vampire hunter, which were almost as much of an unbalanced problematic afterthought as the card game rewards are. Speaking of these card game rewards, which ones have already been met? An nsfw" pack. Yes. A ♥♥♥♥ing nsfw pack of cards for a party game I originally wanted to just open up with friends and play like we would Apples to Apples or maybe the new popular game Secret Hitler.

What's worse is that this Kickstarter is seemingly the only legitimate way of purchasing the soundtrack - of course that's a tier wayyyy above the card deck itself
date: much more expensive than a typical soundtrack would be
recommended: which is about the only thing I'd be looking for. You can't even get the soundtrack if you're under 21
hoursPlayed: thanks to the nsfw cards being bundled with it.\n\nSo I guess my logic is that if I've supported this company multiple times

reviewText:
I'm going to be up front with this: Town of Salem is a great game. That's not why this is a negative review, because everyone should play Town of Salem right now - in their browsers. The Steam version of this game is strictly inferior to the browser version, the only advantage I can possibly think of being that you'll know when your friends are playing without needing to login, assuming they ALSO have the Steam version, which is a $5 investment more than the browser version. As for what makes it worse?

Window settings are not saved when you close the game. It will launch in full screen each and every time. If you want to go into windowed mode, you either need to hit escape, or enter a game and press the full screen button. Upon entering windowed mode for the first time on a fresh launch, the window will be unimaginably tiny and must be manually resized to something functional. To go back to full screen, you MUST enter a game and press the fullscreen button. It cannot be done from the menu.

There is no way to back out of a game, even if you have no chance of winning (e.g. died during the night as a jester, lynched as an executioner). There is also no way to return to the login screen if you timeout.

There is no log out button. The only way to change clients is to exit the client and log back in.

The only instance I would recommend grabbing the Steam version of this game is if you were already planning on buying $5 worth of town points. Seeing as its a browser game to begin with, there's no particular convenience of having it on Steam right now, and the Steam version feels like it was rushed to meet a deadline without any actual attention given to justify its presence here.

Luckily, the devs ARE working on fixing these issues, and I'll be editing this review as they come, and once I feel like the Steam version is a worthwhile buy, I'll change the review to be positive.

reviewText:
As much as I'd like to give a positive review to this once loved game of mine.. I simply can't.

The reason why I cannot give this game a good review is though once this game had some potential.. It screeched to a halt long ago and hasn't moved forward since. The speed of updates to the gameplay have all but stopped, with the devs preferring to make cosmetic skins and maps referencing other media rather than balance the wonky game that lies before us.
The Community for the most part is utterly toxic, with most random lobbies being nearly unplayable with the amount of game-throwers, rage-quitters or meta-gamers. The only time that I would have found fun is with playing with friends and trying to deceive each other, though even that's worn thin.

Combine this with the devs saying that the game is doing better than ever even though it's statistically false after research, the ways that the staff operate on the games forums and a mountain of other things that I won't go into.. And this game has gone downhill like nobodies business.

TLDR; I don't recommend it because it just isn't worth getting for all the issues there are with the game and dev.

This brings back my childhood, i just love it!
I don't know about people outside europe, but here in europe was the game werewolving a real life card which was played on thousands of colleges, schools and friends parties.

This game is the same as werewolving and it's fantastic.

So let's get this game folks, it's worth every cent, and if you are not sure than go ahead and play it for free in your browser.

reviewText: You don't even know how much I recommend this game. I've played this game on the browser version since July 2014, and have loved it since. I recently got the Steam version, which is essentially the same thing but gives you $5 worth of Town Points. Basically, you're paying for the average $5 TP purchase, and the same game but on the Steam platform.\n\nI love the game in general, and I recommend buying it or playing it on the browser. It's a very fun game and if you're into strategy, this is a must. Games usually last around 15 to 25 minutes, and are extraordinarly fun. I play a quick game almost everyday. There's a few Game Modes, including the new Ranked mode which is in beta. The basics of the game is that there's 3 sides: Town, Mafia, and Neutral. You don't know what anyone's role or side is, and you go off of assumptions and your abilities if your role has them. Town has to lynch/kill all of the evil roles, Mafia has to kill anyone who isn't a Witch/Mafia, and as for Neutral, that varies. You have to rely on strategy, and a bit of luck to win. All of the roles are balanced, none of them are OP or underpowered, and there's new roles coming out soon.
voteText: 31 of 34 people (91%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Town of Salem is a Strategic Elimination game that's set the the town of, well, Salem, back when the witch trials were very much alive.

This was a browser game in the past for quite some time, but December 15th is when it's mark on Steam came along. I played the browser version pretty extensively, and it's a very fun game to play because the outcome solely depends on player interaction and decisions.

See, you have these various roles, all with different alliances. Townies try and work together to survive and find out who the bad guys are. The mafia are their own group, trying to eliminate anyone who isn't them. And then the neutrals are people trying to achieve their own goal, neither with townies nor mafia. 15+ roles exist in the game, and they can all have a huge outcome on any game.

What's the catch? You have no idea who is what, so you need to use your smarts and think about whether to trust the people you're with or not. Each day, there's a discussion, then there's voting. If one person is voted to be lynched, they have a chance to defend themselves, then the town decides whether that person is guilty or innocent. The game then transitions to night, where the action happens. People can be stabbed, moved, killed, distracted, just about anything can happen at night, as careful as you may be. The game ends when either the Townies or Mafia wins (Neutrals are rare cases.)

This is why I like this game so much. Like I said, it depends heavily on human interaction, which is what keeps every game fresh and alive. You're always given a random role at the start of a new game. You can pick classic mode where there's a set list of roles, and all 15 players fufill one, or you can do All Any" where you don't know what roles exist
date: and that makes it an even bigger mystery.\n\nOverall
recommended: Town of Salem is an awesome game to play just for the suspensefulness and the fresh variety with every game
hoursPlayed: I really recommend this game."

reviewText:
I used to support this game and gave it a good review, but I feel that the quality has gone downhill. They do not know how to run a community-driven game.

- There are a number of problems with the mechanics of the game (which they have received many suggestions to fix) but updates to the game balance are almost non-existant
- They added a ranked mode but the ELO system is broken and it barely works.
- Rules that can get your account banned if broken are not communicated, just hidden away in the ToS
- The devs choose to focus their resources on updates nobody wants (physical card games, cosmetics like skins and pets, etc).
- They do not take constructive criticism well.
- There is a forum for suggestions and feedback but they almost never even acknowledge the posts, much less implement anything in-game.
- They take things personally and get insulted. They hold grudges against users they see as nay-sayers and there is a feeling that some of the users are a bit elitist and there is favoritism at play.
- They have had 2 kickstarters and a 3rd is planned for the physical card game. They still haven't met the goals of earlier kickstarters and it's hard to imagine their profits are being used appropriately.
- There is a problem with some of the players that they seem unable to deal with (game throwing, leaving while alive, etc)

Bottom line: The idea of this game is amazing, but it's basically just an online version of Mafia or Werewolf. If someone were to make and manage it properly, it could be a wonderful, unique multiplayer experience requiring strategy and manipulation. As it stands, don't bother. Just use their free website to play until you get sick of the BS too.

reviewText:
Pros:


•It is actually an entertaining game. If the stars align and you have a run of good towns, you can have lots of fun with them all and end up wasting hours wondering how to be the best damn Jester you can be.

•The graphics suit the game and it looks rather pretty, especially if you have a town of people with different skins.

•It runs well, on steam at least. When I used to play it from a web client it had lag issues.

Cons:


•You can actually play it for free on a web browser, though you end up with more advertisements and possibly more lag.

•For me, there are four big problems with this game right now, one of which is the scrolls. When you buy the game on steam, you've paid money, so you expect to get a fair game and a stab at all the roles, right? Nope. Thanks to people using scrolls, I've been stuck with crap roles all day today, to the point of getting the same one three times in a damn row, and it gets really disheartening but I don't want to be pushed into a microtransactions battle...

•Leavers. See, even when I did get a crap role I'd still stick a game out and play it the best I could, but it's hard to actually get a good game in when people are allowed to just quit when they get a role they don't like. They need to change how this works, make it so that if people leave a game they have to wait a certain time until they can play again or something, because today I had 5 people leave on the first night. Two of whom were Mediums...

•Bad players.. So you got a role you like and people didn't leave? Well then you're just gonna have the perfect game now, right? Maybe... See, most of the time you end up with people who play a role stupidly (earlier a retributionist brought back a bodyguard. Then the jailor executed the bodyguard), people who throw games for a friend or just to be an idiot (earlier I was in the mafia, one of the mafia members quit and outed all of the mafia in his will), sometimes people will just plain want to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (I don't feel like I need an example here, welcome to the internet), and sometimes people will play together sitting next to each-other irl and just plain cheat (earlier there was a sherrif who somehow INSTANTLY knew all the mafia, from day 2. They even admitted to it later, and told people in the mafia please don't kill my friend")... In a game in which the multiplayer IS THE GAME

reviewText:
Play a good few games in the browser version before you consider purchasing this, the game may not be for you so no point wasting £4.

At first it may look identical to the browser based game but there are definite improvements and differences:
+ The game is faster, loading screens has been cut down a lot
+ You get $5 worth of points which can be used for customisation
+ The game is less glitchy and won't randomly stop working like the browser version, forcing you to leave the game
+ The Steam version links to your current account and all your achievements are carried over
+ You can play with people on the browser version

- It's still the same game at it's heart, don't buy unless you want to actively support the developer
- There's no graphics options such as resolution
- The window can be very buggy and get stuck either in windowed mode or fullscreen
- STILL NO PROPER INGAME VOLUME CONTROL, the music is ridiculously loud as always and can only be turned on and off

reviewText:
Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients
1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar
3/4 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks
2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon fine salt

Directions
1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.

5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.

For a Rocky Road Bar:
1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

reviewText:
The concept of the game is alright. However it is rather poorly executed. The game suffers from a huge lack of balancing especially in Ranked. NK and Mafia have such a hard time in winning in it.

The other main gripe is how much advertising is in the game for microtransactions. I don't mind paying for a game, but when there is a free version and you going to still flash up with 'pay real money for this bundle' it get's annoying. The points are also a grind to earn to actually get things legitimately with ingame currency.

Other than that it is just simpily a social deduction game which seems that most competitors in ranked now have been dropped on the head a few times. Examples - Mayor decided to kill someone who was confirmed on their side, Mafia chooses to kill at a pointless and risky time has the target swapped and kills his own guy and throws the game.

The investigator results are a bit unfair for the mafia as one is a rare role, easily confirmed, or the godfather meaning they are always lynched. Another one is a role which is confirmed kill and a mafia.

I would honestly recommend something like Secret Hitler/Palpatine on Table Top Simulator right now as is. I understand that they cannot change the community on a game like this so they don't troll or do stupid things, it is shame but it is a burden bore by all multiplayer games.

reviewText:
Town of Salem is another Mafia and Werewolf, chat-based game. It's addicting, I don't even know why.

Gameplay revolves around lie and deceit, sometimes on trust, but expect that trust to be shattered on random occasions. As such, game's sometimes filled with hatred, foul language and slanderous remarks, as such it's the nature of the game. Use every caution when playing with teens. Thankfully there's a filter and report function for deterring such toxicity.

To win, you need to see your role and objectives, then act accordingly. More often than not, this requires plenty of experience on examining people's behavior and try to adapt or manipulate them to get your goal done. While it seems easy, in reality it's not. You will see people's reaction very different than you have hoped, thus failing your objective. There are bunch of roles to learn, ranging from good roles e.g Jailor, Medium to badasses (is that even a word?) e.g Mafia, Serial Killer. The roles contradict each others, heck even good guy can kill good guy in chaos, making it confusing. Logic is necessary before you judge.

It's recommended to read the roles carefully and check the wiki every now and then if you get lost somehow.

There are basically two game modes, normal (fun sessions) or ranked (oh-so-damn serious sessions). You need to get certain threshold to unlock the ranked match, which is expected  as thorough knowledge of the game is necessary so you don't ruin others' experience during ranked match.

This version of Town of Salem on Steam is coded on Adobe AIR of which naturally has different issue than, say, outdated graphic/sound drivers. The most common complaint is the inability to even launch the game due to Adobe AIR issue. I honestly think they should've coded this with different engine/programming language. However, due to low requirements, even toasters can run the game. I've had success launching the game on Intel HD-based machine myself.

Some other annoying issues for me personally are:
- inability to minimize the game completely, as it runs on borderless window that can't be minimized. Can be forced into background/inactive window, but that's all.
- You'll also get kicked if you're AFK in normal menu (not in a match with other players) something that I can't understand myself.
- Also, there are random disconnects that force you to restart the game because you stuck in one menu and unable to open, say, lobby or join match.
- Soundtracks are repetitive and boring.
- Microtransactions are shoved on your face. While it's not required to play the game or give any advantage whatsoever, it is annoying to see the pop up every time.

Salem has the data saved on cloud/server-based, so you won't have to worry about your game data unless they shut down the server. You just need to take care of your Steam login and you're set. And to date, the game's still being developed. As of today, I read the news post about new role update about Vampire/Vampire Hunter, which is good knowing it'll add another layer of strategies and... lies.

A bit note of game's replayability - it's very high. Although the mechanic stays the same from session to session, it's not similar experience as you're dealing with different people every time on different sessions (unless you're playing with all friends). Good stuff really.

Now for pricing, for me it seems to be appropriately priced. This Steam version contains in-game coins equal to 5 USD, while the free version (browser version) does not offer such. I got the copy from recent Bundlestars' bundle, though, very cheap around 5 USD for like 9 games.

So, while generally I can appreciate and recommend this game, there are several negative points that must be addressed above. Overall, it will be fun session should you try to play the game.

7.5/10

Now I'm off to kill some big bad guys... and Townies. Yes I'm that good guy and jerk alike.

reviewText:

Some negative things:

- No longer supports login via Facebook :(

These negative things are obviously all insignificant to the positive things.

reviewText:
Town of Salem is a strategic elimination game, like the description says. And it's a great game, if you have friends. However, the gameplay is completely reliant on the IQ of the people you're playing with. If you don't have a party of 5+, you're completely subject to the whims of Salem's community, which is rather... poor.

Back around Salem's conception and early days, the intelligence level was tolerable -- you'd have some games filled with idiots, sure, but they were usually vastly outnumbered by games where you could have a fairly coherent discussion and really get some deception and good plays going. Nowadays, it seems like almost every game is filled with people who talk with their asses and don't know how to read. It could just be terrible luck on my part, but even some of my friends have noticed this trend as well.

Unless you wish to financially support the devs, play the free browser version instead. [blankmediagames.com] It's exactly the same as the steam version.

reviewText:
As a preface, I went into this game knowing exactly what I was in for. I knew the mafia game, I knew (some of) the roles, looked up the rest, I knew that my $5 was more to support the steam release and that I didn't get anything more than $5 of in game currency for cosmetics, I knew that an online version of this would lead to certain issues such as cheating, toxic players, and/or (most commonly) just people leaving/afking. Surprisingly, the game design shows that it's well aware of its own learning curve and provides an opportunity to read all the roles from the main page as well as providing you with any and all information you need about your role in game (for the forgetful and the lazy, I guess).  I like the game, its foundation, and its execution. It does have flaws, however, and I'll explain them below along with its merits.

Things I like:Roles
There are no roles with no point. Every role on every side has SOME kind of special ability or a special win condition that either adds to the depth or intrigue of the game. The exception is survivor, which is exactly what it sounds like. You're simply not rewarded for interacting as a survivor other than to say you're a survivor. A lot of people (in game) rail on the town roles, but I actually find them the most interesting and varied. And the more I play the game, the more I find a use for that role" that seemed so bad before. (Except Disguiser. Mechanically
date: you have to hope someone was bad for that role to work. Or you need an accompanying janitor.)\nThe whisper system\nWhen you first play
recommended: the whisper system seems almost out of place and like an obvious way to stand out. People who actually utilize it are among the strongest percentage of players. EVIL players able to get in on those networks are among the best liars in the game. Even if you have the presence of mind to try and nip things in the bud by attacking those who start the network
hoursPlayed: you actually run a huge risk because a protective role with the same presence of mind as you could make you waste a turn or potentially kill you. Every play you make is an exercise in risk/reward management.\nThis is an intellectual game\nThis game is an exercise in a large number of intellectual skills

reviewText: Okay, first of all this is much as the browserversion in full-screen mode, if not the same. But let´s be real You pay 5 Euros, not only for the game, but you get the equal amount of in game money worth of what you pay, which is a good deal from my perspectiv. The reason behind it, is that it can take a long time to get in game money, for buying new skins or caracters, but with buying the steam version, not only do you get some money for new things, you also get a more convinient version of the game, since (atleast in my opinion) steam is easily accesed. But with that out of the way, i think that the game is worth buying, and more so if you have some friends or know some people who might be intrested in playing a game with you over a voice calling program and having a great time together. Just remember the game is not perfect in the 1.0.0 version, since it does not auto-login into the game in the steam version, and there is some few bugs here and there, but it is not something that is gamebreaking in my opinion. So yeah, Buy the game if you feel like supporting the developers and get some in game money in the process. BTW sorry for the long post, but i had to get my point out :)

I've played a bit of the browser version, and it's fun. Spent lots of time on it. But here are some of my highlights.

Named myself Werewolf, sadly didn't get the role Werewolf. Night 2, I was attacked by the Werewolf. Wanna know what else happened? http://prntscr.com/5dqhbu That's right, if I'm going down, I'm bringing 4 people down with me.
Named myself Jailor, got the role Jailor. I killed a Arsonist second night, a Framer third night, and a Blackmailer the fourth. The funny thing was that I had no leads except what they told me during the night. (I didn't guess, they told me wrong information)

The only bad thing is that most games you have idiots. Having constant fullscreen is also annoying, for people like me who like playing without fullscreen. Otherwise, amazing game.

reviewText:
Pointing fingers, telling lies, to what end?  Well not to get hung that's why.  It's a game of who dunnit in the small town of Salem.  The day becomes a murder mystery as you try to figure out who possibly killed the citizens of Salem the night before.

Use your special abilities to determine/confuse/trick/frame and even restrain your neighbors in this hilarious game of murder mystery.

Extremely fun and often silly when you get blamed for being the serial killer, for pointing out the fact that your neighbor likes to use knives(Could be a serial killer or a doctor).  Please give this game a try, it's quite fun and the matchmaking system is extremely fast.

Easily a 8/10 for fun factor.   Only down side is a few missing features and it takes an extremely long time to gather gold coins to purchase new skins for customization.

Overall, highly recommended.

reviewText:
YOU DO NOT NEED TO BUY THIS ON STEAM.
You can play ToS as free browser game here: http://www.blankmediagames.com/TownOfSalem/
However, buying the 5€ version via Steam gives you a lonestanding application, which runs faster and is more comfortable, 5€ worth of ingame skins and stuff (no actual gameplay-relevant content, it's true free2play) and support the devs. As well, they might stop updating the browser version in the future.

The game itself is 'Mafia', the well-known forum/party/RPG game. It has a lot of roles and diversity, multiple rounds, and due to timers a game is over in ~20 minutes.
If you like the  Mafia-game genre, I can warmly recommend this game.

Rating: 8/10. Annoying music, a tad simple graphic, but the gameplay is perfectly fine once you learn how the roles work. Test it out for free on the site and buy it once you love it.

reviewText:
Town of Salem is a very good game.

It is a slow paced multiplayer turn strategy game where the Chat plays a crucial factor. Each player receives a role from a made up list of 15 out of 30 total roles in the game. Actual mechanical options of each role are actually limited compared to blockbuster strategy games, but still they are very distinctive and important. The way you choose to interact the game will actually impact your chance to win and there is a high skill cap despite the limited mechanics. Still taking a casual aproach can be very fun.

There is a free version of the game which is equal to the steam one, but just because its free doesnt mean its not worth 5 dolars.

Even if you like the concept of a slow paced different game like this, there are as of now 2 turn offs that Id like to point:

- No Ranked Play: According to the developers this is the next thing being implemented shortly. Still this means that as an average player you will face almost every game people less commited than you (including a big amount of quitters) and ocasionally games where everyone is more commited than you and will become upset at your aproach.

- No hard option to browse custom games or to create a custom room: Custom rooms are where the real games happen. This means sometimes you will want to play a balanced, advanced standard game and the host will either try to make something very unusual or unbalanced. Or you will be looking for a unusual game and will have to hop in and out of rooms for minutes (you can only join a new room once the previous is full of 15 people) until you have the luck to be host or find something you like.

Still a fantastic game which already delivers what it promises and can only improve and as far as i know a new, very good concept.

9/10 Would spend 10 minutes trying to host a custom game again to have someone quit on the 1st turn on a balance imprescindible role and ruin it for everyone. Many times.

reviewText:
Town of Salem
Roleplay game based on communication between players - and that's the funny part - when there is no-one to trust. The mafia claims to be the member of the town, town members are afraid to reveal their roles because of the mafia. But how to find tha mafia and convince enough players to lynch them. That's up to you to find out. Don't expect this to entertain you when you don't want to cooperate, if you are talkative or just really able to get into your role, this is something for you.

Few advises:

#1 LIE! LIE! LIE!
#2 Everybody lies, don't trust anyone
(expecially not your friends, even the one you are on teeamspeak with!)
#3 Ones with the most attention-grabbing names, die first!

7/10

reviewText:
Played as mafia with three others.
I chatted a lot with one particular townie.
Later, fellow disguiser disguised as the townie, who I cleaned as Janitor.
Turned out to be medium - only I knew.
Next night, I was jailed, and at the same time, the dead medium seanced me.
Dead medium told me who the disguiser was, and I told the jailor the disguiser was someone else, shocking both dead medium (when he figured out he'd just seanced the mafia) and the jailor (because I accidentally accused him of being disguiser).
Next morning, jailor died, mafia wins, and we all celebrated with a toast.

10/10

TL;DR

Pros:
Excellent game, with cool skins, background, music and great roleplaying fun. Personal favorite is neutral roles. If you want to play something casual to pass the time, this is perfect for the job.

Cons: Certain roles can be really boring/stressful. Also you may have to deal with obnoxious/♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ players sometimes.

reviewText:
Worst playerbase I have ever seen.
People on skype calls cooperating while being on opposing teams.
People completely arbitrarily helping someone who is supposed to be their enemy, even when they have a good chance of winning.
People refusing to learn most basic and essential mechanics (wills, invest clues).
Almost every game, 2-3 people leave right at the start.

Perhaps it's different in ranked. However, I've been unable to join any ranked games. Client disconnects after about 30 seconds of staying on home screen without joining any games (some culling of inactive connections, I presume - just have to restart for it to work again) - not an issue in non-ranked play, but queues for ranked are long enough for disconnection to occur, so it can never join a lobby. Might just be a very specific issue only I have, idk.

The game itself is quite good and can be a lot of fun, but not with such a playerbase. I hoped it would get better some time after launch, when those who have more interest in trolling and derping around than in the actual game quit, but nope. Still the same, perhaps even worse.

It's still recommended if you have enough friends with some free time to play only with them. But not otherwise. Unless you just want to annoy and grief people or enjoy that being done to you.

reviewText:
I have been playing Town of Salem for months now and found it has become the core of my youtube channel in it's beta. This is a game where everyone is on an equal level. There are no overpowereds or underpowereds there is just you, a group of people and your wits. Town of Salem is an inspired system that brings a popular party game beyond it's humble beginnings and creates a truly spectacular and frequently updated system where you and your friends can have the most fun playing off against each other and still come out the end laughing. The aim of the game is simply to fulfill the goials of one of many roles either Saving the town from the menaces of the mafia or becoming the monster within the town and making the peasants bow at your feet. Alternatively you can become a murderous killing machine who wants everyone dead or be a poor innocent caught up in the crossfire who wants nothing more than to survive. Or maybe you just want to find the truth of who you are. The Roles within can consume hours of fun working out strategies using or even being against these roles.

The game also benefits from caring and considerate Developers who have proven time and again they have the communities best intrests at heart with kickstarter reward fulfilled at every turn and promises that are kept and an undeniable desire to make the game better.

Town of Salem is a truly amazing game that deserves it's recognition by far. Already it has turned the intrest of many big name and small youtubers alike. Everyone should play this game at least once. It's one of the very best indie games out there.

reviewText:
As many have said before me, this is an excellent game. If you enjoy Werewolf or Mafia, then this is one of those perfect games to sit back and relax to. Money has become signifigantly easier to obtain recently even though its still pretty hard to make quick cash but to be honest, it's not like cash provides anything non-aethstic. Also the creators are very dedicated and have been continously updating and improving the game since I've first joined it months ago and hold their players in very high regards. Each game should take about 20 minutes, so plan accordingly. Remember that if you leave a game early, you dont get the smaller loss reward which is better than no reward.

Now, what's different about the steam version?

The main thing that you get with the steam version is simply the $5.00 town points for buying the game and the lack of advertisements for owning the game. One VERY noticeable difference is that the Steam version runs much faster and much more smoother than the browser version and has little to no lag which has been very beneficial to me and has prevented me from returning to the Browser version. Some people are asking how to leave a game early and it's almost the same way as the browser version, click ESC to get out of full screen mode, close the game client, and load it back up. The creators do not have a back to home button in either version and it is something they are working on. The game should be adding a few more roles after it's recent kickstarter.

reviewText: I really have had some great times playing this game.  In theory, it's a great game about deception, teamwork, and puzzle-solving.  In practice, the toxic homophobia, sexism, racism, and general d0uchebaggery of many of the community members has sucked all of my enjoyment out of the game.  If they ever actually do something to deal with the players who make the game impossible to enjoy, I'll come back, but I have seen no evidence that reporting gamethrowers, leavers, and the above-described bigots does anything.  If they are being removed, then new ones are coming in at an alarming rate.  It just isn't fun for me anymore, so even though I've played this game for a lot of hours and had some really good experiences with it, I can't recommend it to anyone and I'm deleting it from my computer.  Fix the community and I'll fix my review.

reviewText:
After so little hours (yes for this game that is true) it's obvious this game is a must buy at least at discount price if base price is too much. Why? because if you have never played a live chat MP game where paranoia and investigation (and ultimately survival) is key then you need to try this. So grab a random role and try to hide it away from others - until it's time to step up - or not - depending on your role and situation.

I suppose the biggest brilliance of this game is that it overcomes easily the '12yo XDXD le troles bringing the bantz' because a) they dont want to play this as they are the underdogs quickly. Players appear semi-mature atleast b) The more stupid you act the more likely you get random lynched which gives more time for others to form the real game ending.

i'd say this game is almost immune to trolling as fooling others is the name of the game. Gamethrowing aka people quitting is not much of a trouble either because even if half the people quit it still doesnt matter - epic and surprising endings are aplenty as games are decided in the last turns usually.

reviewText:
Town of Salem brings the crazy role-countering party game “Mafia” onto browsers/digital screens, and despite its drab presentation, proves to be dastardly sinister fun.

NOTE: You can play the game for free on browser at the game’s site.
Pros:Dynamic classes that all counter other classes or play major roles in the game.
Complex Features; Normally Mafia’s gameplay is simplistic to keep it understandable as a party game, but they went full out in this game, with tons of abilities, new classes + the mix of Werewolf, Neutral Classes, and Last Wills.
The Emergent Interaction with other players is fantastic and fun.
Netcode is done very well; No matter how poor the connection I was able to play the game and interact with everybody just fine.
Nitpicks:No Private Lobbies, which I think is disappointing because having a full group of friends together would really make this establish itself as a party/LAN game.
Generic as hell music. I just ended up muting it eventually.
Steam Version does not save settings; when I boot the game it doesn’t know that I previously switched it to windowed. Really annoying.
Cons:Drab and boring presentation; as a flash game, it can run on a toaster, but it doesn’t excuse it from it’s menus being unintuitive and not-so-good-looking and it’s visual artstyle from looking so cheap.
Microtransactions aren’t a big deal since the only purchasable items are really cosmetics, but the class scrolls are a horrible item that is either incredibly useless or unfair, contradicting what makes the game so good.
Friends System is glitched and broken, usually doesn’t update or send notifications to others, making it frustrating to organize events with friends.
The Review
Town of Salem is very simple to explain to those who often go out on parties. It’s basically Mafia/Werewolf, except as a video game! It takes the advantage of complex mechanics (that can easily be done in games versus as a party game) to elevate Town of Salem as a much more dynamic game. There are a lot more countering between the roles, which means there’s a whole lot more to keep up with. This is what makes Town of Salem a much more fresh experience.

There’s so many things to keep track of too. You’ve got escorts that can distract players, jailors that can interrogate others and execute them, there’s just so much going on. There’s Last Wills, a Serial Killer role, neutral roles that can get caught in the crossfire, unique Town roles besides just “Citizen”, and so much more. If you plan on playing it’s competitive matchmaking, you have to keep every aspect of the game in mind.

Add Werewolf in the mix, and you get pure insanity. That doesn’t mean you have to play with the Werewolf roles, however. Town of Salem allows for custom matches where you can pick the roles, which will definitely make for a lot more creativity and unique game modes to pop up.

How ever, it has to be said that it’s presentation is really, really bad. If it’s loading times, far from serviceable graphics and bad UI makes it a lot less appealing. While the loading times aren’t as bad as the browser version, and the graphics can be more of a nitpick at this point, the horrible UI can not be excused. It takes so many clicks to do actions that could had easily be cut down, the various windows for the game are placed all over, and the UI while in a game completely clutters the screen. It’s a good thing you can do something about the in-game one though, but those with low monitor resolutions are not going to have a good time.

It’s visuals are honestly subpar, but it can be excused for it being a flash game (Why it is a flash game in the first place will forever confuse me). However, what I found really grating was it’s cheap and horrible music/sound design. It’s music was generic as hell, and the sound effects were cheesy and annoying at best. It’s easier if you just tune into your own music while playing.

The microtransactions generally consist of mainly cosmetics, so it’s not that big of a deal. However, the BS that is the scrolls are completely obnoxious. Purchasing scrolls allow you to get a higher chance of a certain role, which completely ruins the RNG factor that is picking the roles in Mafia. It stoops the gameplay very low, and it’s really sad that people will have less of a chance to pick roles people have put scrolls towards.

However, in practicality, the scrolls end up actually being a total waste of coins, because you’ll probably not get the role anyway. It basically turns what is a game-breaking item into a useless item at the same time.

So let’s talk about organizing the game as a party game. It can work, but it’s ultimately a huge disappointment. There’s no private lobbies, meaning if you have less than 15 people, you will have to play with randoms. Due to the messy UI and bad friend system getting in the way, sending up lobbies can become a hectic mess. Sometimes, it doesn’t update whatever or not a player is online, meaning sending them an invite is virtually impossible.

The Steam version (besides loading times and the fact that it isn’t free) is fine. You get some in-game currency and better loading times since you’re running on a client versus a browser, but if you don’t want to pay for an experience like this, you really don’t have to get it on Steam. Also, it does not save any of it’s settings on the Steam version, which means I always have to toggle “No Fullscreen” and “Mute Music” settings when I get the chance.

But besides that, what can I say? It’s Mafia. Despite the disappointing aspects of the game, I still find it to be a solid time killer and definitely a complex and entertaining game. Tarnation indeed.

TL;DR - Although disappointing some aspects, Town of Salem is still a fun and very playable game.

For more reviews on all sorts of games, follow  Lots' o Giveaway's group curations and reviews  here!

reviewText:
Paid version of a browser-based game: http://www.blankmediagames.com/TownOfSalem/

Besides that? One of the best and funniest party games I've played in a long while. It's based on the Starcraft 2 mod Mafia, and it is set in an alternative universe of Salem, where a group of 15 players must lynch or kill those who are not on their side, there is the Townies, the Mafia, Serial Killers, Survivors, Arsonists, Witches and Werewolves (Survivors, Arsonists, Witches and WWs are only in the Custom gamemode, and Classic can only have 1 SK.)

The townies have to gather clues from previous deaths, other players, your class ability and guessing in order to hang or kill all the Mafia and the Serial Killer. The Mafias must kill all the townies and hang the SK, while the SK has to lynch the Mafias and Townies but he can kill on his own.

The game has a nice artwork and charm to it, and the player characters range from fitting and nice, to advertising like a shameless ♥♥♥♥♥. The houses you can have ranges from classical houses that usually were built during the time of Salem to a ♥♥♥♥ing Balloon house. The pets range from faries to Doge. Yes, the meme.

The players can be from very clever to just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and roleplaying racists. The devs are planning to add in a ranked mode which should get rid of most of the annoying people, so that's really great, because being a Medium and having dead players quit is the ♥♥♥♥ing worst.

That said, play it on the browser then if you like it? Come over here and give over your 5$ for 1300 coins, and support the devs.

reviewText:
Great game, but sadly this version really is a step back from the online version.

Let me tell you what bugs me about this version:
- In a web browser you close the game by closing the tab, and since the game is a direct port from the website version and offers no new buttons like e.g. a close button, you CAN'T close the game without killing it! I mean c'mon, why do we HAVE to close the game via Alt+F4?
- When you get asked if you want to share an achievement or a won game on facebook this works perfectly fine in the website version. However, in the Steam client version the window doesn't pop up, which denies one 25 gold per share.
- Only Full Screen mode.
- Updates have slowed down already since the release of this version.

Conclusion:
This version has it's problems, but I'm not here to rate the version, I'm here to rate the game.
The game itself is pretty darn funny and enjoyable, I can only recommend you to play it, but preferably for free on the website. If you'd like to support the team go ahead and purchase ingame coins or donate, but I wish I would have waited to buy the client since it just looks clunky and unfinished.

EDIT:
Exit button was added, seems like they solve problems now :)

reviewText:
The Good
The game is a lot of fun under the right circumstances and offers a fun and unique way to play. Imagine a party game meets clue where a group can win.

The Bad
The graphics are very basic and gameplay can be completely one sided.

The Ugly
There is no reason to purchase the game on steam when it's available for free online.
Players can invite friends to a party, allowing them to always control the game setup and cheat to win.
Game balance can be completely thrown off with friends playing in a party, having too many of one group type, etc.
Impossible to set up your own lobby and game rules as you are usually thrown into someone else's lobby or a party of friends will call a repick to get host.
If players are friends and refuse to take each other out or too dumb to guess who to vote against, game lasts a long time.
Players can throw the game by sharing secrets, quitting, etc.

reviewText:
I was doused in gas the first night, but being a crazed arsonist myself, I was able to clean the gas off of me. I told everyone I was just an innocent surivor, while I let my other arsonist friend douse everyone. When he ignited all the doused targets and saw I was still alive, he instantly knew I was working with him. We worked together to douse the remaining townies and mafia. Then I ratted him out. We lynched him and everyone thought they were safe. And that night I ignited and watched every single one of them burn. I walked out of my house in the morning, and smiled at all the dead, charred bodies laying on the ground. I was the only survivor.

Then I walked back inside my house and played Town of Salem. This game is absolutely great! I completley recommend it to anyone and everyone! Liars! Cheaters! Scumbags! Aliens who don't understand a word you say! Those seem to be the only players I'm matched with anyway.

reviewText:
The game is very good but there are a few issues with it:

1.  Game was originally based on a web version, and still holds to the same UI.  While it's nice that all my friends don't have to pay 5 bucks to play with me, it doesn't feel so much an in-game menu as it does a popped out webpage.  Not a huge problem, just not very aesthetically pleasing.

2.  Game was originally free, and there seems to still be a very big push to convince (paying customers mind you) to buy extra coins.  By that I mean the speed at which you earn in-game currency is abominable.  I've bought 2 customization items in all the time that I've been playing this game.  2.  In 25 hours.  For a game I payed for.  Seems pretty dumb to me, just saying.

3.  Very little moderation.  While I personally don't mind profanity, I'd really have liked to play this with my younger siblings, but I'm not going to expose them to a community that casually calls eachother racist and homophobic slurs.  My mother would kill me if I did that.

That being said, the game is fantastic.  I don't think I've enjoyed a game this much since I first started playing Dark Souls.  I wouldn't recommend buying it though, go on the web browser version until they fix the emphasis on the cash store for people who have already paid.

reviewText: Town of Salem is a party game based on mafia/werewolf. It can have a steep learning curve at first, but once yer' good at it it's a great way to make friends and have fun. You should also get to know the memes that players have come up with in this game. If you don't know what the medium's curse is yet, then get playing!\n\nAlso, for those who don't know, this game is free on browser, so I'd recommend trying it there first, and then getting it on Steam if you enjoy it. I'd sunk tons of hours into the browser version before the Steam release.

reviewText:
A great simplistic game that reveals into a complicated mind game.
This game has brought me many great experiences and would highly reccomend if you even consider playing it.
Buying the steam version of the game gives you a little bit of payed currency that can be used for cosmetics, but buying the game on steam is not needed. but I noticed It did feel alot more smooth and better once I used the client version.

My best memory to date with Town of Salem has to be the time I played as a Vigilante. This role is a town friendly role that can take matters into their own hands and shoot someone. I accidently shot another town member and my character took their own life. However, the Bodyguard role visited my house that night and protected me from harm making him stop my character from shooting themself, because of this my character shot him and died. ~ Pretty complicated and took me a while to understand why a bodyguard died protecting me ;)

reviewText:
If you don't want to buy it on steam, you don't have to. The game is COMPLETELY free on the browser version, but if you want to support the game (like I did) you get $5 worth of currency (If you have ever played League of Legends, it is basically RP). This game is extremely fun for those who like mystery/mafia games and I reccomend it to people that are into using clues and decieving others.

If you want to try the game without a steam purchase, play it for free on the website. If you do  decide to buy the steam version later, all of your unlocked achievements/skins will transfer over.

The game is great, it is a newly released game and I can see lots of updates rolling in eventually.

reviewText: Okay, There are tuns of funny reviews on this game. Im not as clever as those folks, so here it is. Town of Salem is a wonderful text based game with lies and murder. Half the people are lying to you. The other half is trying to convince you that they are who they say they are. Its a blast. I most often play it alone. But you can play it with your pals.\n\nIts best when playing with friends to tell eachother your names but not your roles. Since they will ususally hear your keyboard and find out what your name is rather quickly. Tradeing information outside of the game, or Skypeing" is not fun for the people playing including yourself. Along with the fact that any player who has played WAY to much like me will notice in a heartbeat what your doing. The actaul visual interface is not even nessesairy
date:
but its a fun way to add more debth to the game.

I suggest learning the game by playing the game mode "Custom Any" (Custom Game Mode -> All Any.) its named that for good reason. I won't go into it but you will find out.

Honestly I have payed A LOT more for games I havent liked. I paid $5.00 for this game. Since that day I have had SOO much fun playing this. Weather its a binge sesson of 10 games or im at work and I pull it up while im sitting on hold.

I hope you give this game a try. I cannot discribe how much I enjoy it. 10/10 would pay for again.

reviewText:
TL;DR
I highly recommend this game!

IntroductionThis review of a friend of mine drew my attention toward this game. Having played the similar StarCraft II mod Mafia"
date: I was intrigued and tried it out on BlankMediaGames' website HERE[blankmediagames.com] for free.\n\nAfter a whole night of playing it
recommended: I decided I had to buy it. It was incredibly fun.\n\nBuying Town Of Salem on Steam supports the developers and grants you $5 worth of the in-game currency (gold) with which you can buy cosmetic items. You can also earn more gold by completing certain tasks within the game
hoursPlayed: which I would say is a fair business model.\n\nAbout the gameTown Of Salem is a multiplayer-only game based on the party game Mafia[en.wikipedia.org]. It features a team of townsfolk who have to work together to find out who the evil people in the town are and have to get rid of them by hanging them or killing them off in various other ways. The tricky part is that the townsfolk don't know their allies
voteText: while members of the Mafia know exactly who they are working with. The serial killer is essentially a lone wolf and tries to kill everyone else.\n\nThere are fun alternative modes with more roles
helpfulPercent: several of them evil or neutral
votesHelpful: which can make the game much easier or harder
votesTotal: depending on the size of the teams and the distribution of roles.\n\nThere is so much more to this game that I would love to write about in great detail
votesFunny: but for the sake of getting to the point I'm gonna cut it short a bit here and will move on to other aspects now. Besides
commentsCount: the game's description on the store page has got you covered on more details about the gameplay
column16: so check it out. :)\n\nTechnologyBeing built in Flash Action Script
column17: Town Of Salem's graphics and animations are rather rudimentary. However
column18: this kind of game does absolutely not need advanced graphics and especially not animations
column19: so I suppose anything developed in that area is to be considered a plus.\n\nI haven't encountered any problems with the game's online features/servers so far
column20: so to me those seem to be reliable.\n\nSo what I'm saying is: technologically this game gets the job done
column21: doesn't have major issues and isn't horrible to look at.\n\nConclusionIf you enjoy strategy games based on bluffing
column22: this game is absolutely for you. Bear in mind that it can only be played with other people online and that it almost entirely relies on communication with said people via chat. Personally
column23: this game got me hooked.\n\nThere are a few shortcomings that naturally occur as soon as other people are involved
column25: players leaving the game immediately after finding out they were assigned a role they don't like. This is absolutely not the developers' fault though
column26: but as far as I know
column27: they're working on a solution to encourage people more to keep playing.\n\nI have played Town Of Salem for about 35 hours on Steam thus far (+ at least 5 hours through their website)."

reviewText:
I'm a kickstarter backer and I've played countless rounds of this game and while I enjoy the game itself  I would highly advise not buying it.   The community is terribly toxic.   If player's behaviors weren't bad enough cheating is currently a issue as well.  It's got so rampent that some groups don't even bother to hide it.  Then there are the trolls that mean to throw the games to ensure your team loses.     15 people per town and almost always you will have one toxic player spamming the chat with your typical racist, sexist, and homophobic nonsense.

Don't buy this game if you really want to play it use the F2P version which lets you play with Steam owners anyways.  This is how the toxic players all play as well so if they get banned they simply come right back.    The  horde of trouble makers is so immense that the developers are making a trail" system in which the community will police itself by being able to review flagged players in games  and  basically decide if they are guilty or not.    But this just shows how bad the community really is that the developers can't handle it and are passing the responsability to you.    Furthermore once again this won't stop anything as they will come back with new free accounts.      A terribly lazy and flawed plan by the devs.

This game doesn't deserve your money and I regret giving it mine."

reviewText: A few months ago, I would have given this a great review. It was a game to help pass the time between my lectures and actually had some sort of strategic aspect. I mostly played ranked games and they were amazing, After the past few months, however, I have watched ranked play crumble with gamethrowers and spammers. It just isn't fun anymore. The staff do not punish repeat offenders, so the same people continue to spam/throw games on a constant basis (who are also the most active players as of recent)\n\nIt seems as though the staff only care about the money at this point. The lag/DCs are the users fault, because the server never goes down." Although people have complained about the game lag and DC periods in the middle of games
date: the staff deny this ever happens and tells the users to "check their connection."\n\nThere is also a lot of back and forth on "rules" of what is and isn't gamethrowing. One minute the staff agrees on a rule
recommended: the next they change their minds and say something is no longer gamethrowing. Consistency has ALWAYS been an issue and continues to get worse.\n\nI don't reccomend this game to anyone at this point."

reviewText: Your in a little town of salem with 14 other players (total of 15 players),  You are given a role out of town (15 options), mafia  (9 options), and Neutral (9 options).  Each role has a goal, normally to survive or defeat the people in the town that oppose you.  This game forces you to either work with others as a team, mafia vs town, or decieve the town into killing each other...or perhaps yourself.\nThe games last about 20 minutes, but its amazing how many people rage quit after discovering they have a less exciting role as the previous game, therefore ruining the game for the rest of the players.

reviewText:
I know I currently don't have many hours clocked playing this on steam, but i've played this game quite a bit on the web browser. I do like this game but it has some things that need to be notcied.

PROS:
*Roleplaying, You can pick your own name and you get a different role(or maybe the same sometimes) every game.
*Skins, You don't have to buy skins to look different, in the option section you can pick from 5-6 defaults.
*Deception, Tricking players and outsmarting players is somewhat easy.
*Chat Filter, You can have the option to censor swears others put in the chat.
*Rage-Childs, You gotta love those kids who rage so hard when they lose.
*Not Pay-to-play, Note, yes its $5 on steam, but that gives you points ingame for customizations like skins and such. You could just play it on the web browser for free. But those points, don't give you an advantage. They just make you look cooler.

CONS:
*Slow type lag, Most of the time you'll end up typing, but by the time you finish, you notice the game is still inputing the beginning for the message. Which can cause you to mess up badly. Very rarely you end up with the games where you can type quickly and it inputs it just as quick.
*Exclusive Chat Filter, It doesn't include racism.
*Racism, There is a ton of children who rage so much they feel its necessary to call you a Jew, or they feel like its okay to call you a N" word.
*Know-It-alls

reviewText:
It's a great game, with a typically good community and lots of replayability...
The game's chaotic social aspect is also really funny...
That being said though, why anyone would buy this game without trying it out for free online first is beyond me. But it's worth every penny on Steam. :D

Those who claim they didn't get the 5$ worth of in-game $ probably didn't read or follow the instructions in the notifications that popped up in the screen the second they made a game account.
Those who claim there are no tutorials... go online and look at the wiki. Or don't, and play a few matches, and learn how to play somewhat adequately that way too. The game's simple enough that it doesn't need too much of a tutorial once you've read the roles list on the wiki.

*edit* In hindsight, feel free to check my games list. Playtime doesn't lie, this game is freaking amazing.

reviewText:
IntroductionTown Of Salem is party game where players are assigned roles that are aligned to the town (innocent), neutral (mixed) or mafia. The aim of the game to use your role's abilities to help aid your team to victory. Each session is just as unpredictable as the last one. Personally I would reccomend playing All Any mode (Under the Chaos section) since the roles are randomized and no one knows what roles are game, it makes the game more interesting.

Pro and Cons
Pros

1. The game has variety of modes to choose from.
2. It's easy to play, but takes a while to master.
3. The game is addictive, fun and competitive.
4. The game is regularly updated, so the game is kept fresh with new content such as roles, skins, houses etc.
5. The microtransaction system is good and doesn't unbalance the game.

Cons

1. The scrolls system reduces the chances of players getting certain roles unless they purchase some scrolls.
2. Some players don't stick to their given alignments and favour other people. (Which leads to gamethrowing.)
3. The report system is rubbish and most rulebreakers don't recieve punishments.

I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique experience from a game and a enjoyable game. :D
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is a brilliant simulation of the game mafia and werewolf and if you love those games Im definit you will love town of Salem.
While this is a great game it does have alot of issue's and well before buying the game I want to point somethings out to help.
This game was originally a F2P indie game that was later grinlit and released on steam and by buying this game you will receive 1400 in game coins which is the price of 5$.
So essentially you are playing a F2P game with some ingame currency.
With these coins you can buy skins-pets-houses-maps and scrolls wich I will get in later.
Everything except the scrolls in this game is pure accessories and does not reflect your skill or chances of winning in the game but the scrolls they are a different story.
As you might have known this game has 31 roles and these scrolls basically increase your chances of becoming a role you like.
Oh and I forgot to menchion that the coins can be obtained in game without paying money and well the game gives you such a small amount of coins that its essentially like a Pay to win kind of currency.
Well here's where the scrolls and the coins realy mess things up in the game.
Because of the games role system players often leave matches if they didnt get the role they want and decrease the chances of you winning thus decrease the amount of coins you get.
I think if you are realy interested in buying the game first try out the F2P version.
If I sounded a little bit harsh I mean of course I did I just want to point out that I love this game and  I enjoyed every second I played it.

date:

The Obvious - This inculdes people like Jesters and sometimes All of the Mafia vote someone guilty when they are obviously innocent which makes the game really easy.

There are many more types of Trolls in this game but these are the ones I encountered the most.This is a really good game don't get me wrong but I wish The Community was a little better."

reviewText:
>Play mafioso
>Use a name of an anime character
>Have your death note include a reference to said anime
>Have 3 separate people immediately call you out as mafia or sk after first kill


Anyway the game:

Town of Salem is a kind of game that I would sincerely recommend for anyone without any hint of sarcasm or exaggeration. Basically it's a kind of fun social/party game where each player gets a role as a town member, a mafia member or a serial killer role, and the objective of the game is to get rid of every player not in your faction. This is done mainly by chatting with the other players, sharing clues about their roles and accusing them for being evil. This in turn can lead the accused to be lynched during the day or bum tarnationed at night.

That's pretty much the main gist of the game and it includes so many variables that make this game pure genius. The only complain I can think of is that this game really feels like it should be F2P since it's a fairly simple browser game and it even has an in-game store where you can buy cosmetics and other kinds of different flummery. Nonetheless that doesn't make the game bad by any means and it's only like 6€ in the store anyways and I'd say it's worth every cent. You should totally buy it.



A pro's guide to how to play jester:

Don't say a word all game. Upon lynching claim invest. gg

What you're paying $5 for is the steam achievements and support for the devs. This is basically like a donation to them to help evolve the game. They have goals they're trying to accomplish like bringing the game to mobile and creating new customizable content in game. When you do buy this game you are rewarded in game currency automatically so you can buy a skin or something before you even play your first game. If you played this game in browser you would have to play games to get the currency so you don't start off with the money like you would here. Long story short
column35:
buying the game is giving them $5 to their gofundme project and helping support them and recieving updates with the game more often.

*Overall:
I would totally in a heart beat recommend this game to anyone who:
>Likes casual

reviewText:
For the few hours i played this game , i had so much fun it's a very addictif game the atmosphere is really cool with good music , in the beggining you will be lost between roles and what you should do and not do but in no time you will be an expert at this .

First of all there is 29 roles in the game , each one with their own abilities and attributes (your role will be chosen randomly) you can be the mafia godfather and give 0 ♥♥♥♥s and kill enyone you want to or be the doctor and heal someone every night to save him from attacks.

Every round of the game starts with an input of your alias for that game, you do get your own username for game lobbies and friend requests but in-game you get your own separate name to give it that sense of anonymousness to the game as well as to stop any player troll targeting. Then, each player is given their role, which comes with a number of abilities and an allegiance to one of three ‘sides’: The Townies, who’s primary goal is to eliminate all evil roles, The Neutrals, who all have their own unique goals such as ‘Survive till the end of the game’ and ‘Kill everyone who would oppose you” and the Mafia, who’s primary goal is to eliminate the Townies. The game proceeds by to the actual game, which proceeds on a day and night cycle with many stages within.

The goal of the Town (or Townies) is to kill all the Mafia, and other hostile neutrals, such as the serial killer or arsonist. The Mafia's aim to kill all the Townies, and any hostile neutrals. The Neutrals have a variety of goals relating to their individual roles. Generally, the Neutrals don't have a particular side. Deception is a massive part of controlling and winning the game. There is what we call night and day, during the day you can vote on people to lynch them. At night people get killed by the mafia, serial killer, etc.

Pros and cons:
1-Pros
-Alot of roles which improve different play style
-Fun
-Playable with friends
-Easy to learn
-Good music
2-Cons
-Diying 1st night can be booring
-Random lynching
-Afk/Leavers
-some lags

Conclusion :
I really liked to play this game it's very addictif and i had lot of fun specially when i play with a friend we have to trick other players into believing us .

Town of Salem is available on all internet browsers and Steam, for free on browsers and for  5$ on Steam.

This game revolves completely around your team mates both taking the game seriously and not being idiots.

Bottom line: If you plan to take the game seriously and hardcore win, you'll have an aneurysm from the rage. If you just want to mess around and have a good time, this game has plenty of that for 5 bucks.

reviewText:
Town of Salem is a cartoony witch trial simulator. Quick matchmaking and large community fills up the wait queues very fast. Roles are handed in secret, play your role and help your team wins. The learning curve is very manageable as most of the roles are intuitive enough.

Value is not very clear here as the concept is a rip off from SCII custom map and the dev decided to add a cash shop on top of the game not being free to play. You can earn the rewards through enough grind and the rewards are mostly cosmetic except for an item which lets you pick a role.

All in all I have a lot of fun in this game, and everything that ruins other communities like immaturity and trolling end up reinforcing this game's concept, making the trials hilarious and all in all people really do want to play their roles and win so the competitive edge can be very present, and when things go wrong then it is comedy gold even when the reasons are a little dubious. If you find this in a bundle I would say you owe it to yourself to try this. However if you own starcraft II already you might find this version of the game is slightly underpar in comparison to the free custom map. Its up to the dev to raise the bar for its steam release.

reviewText:
7.3/10 - The Town of Salem... at it again!

It’s how I image the real Salem Witch Trials went, a group of people meet in the town square to point fingers at other people. It's quite fun!

You assume one of a plethora of roles such as doctor, serial killer, jailer etc... The town must work together and find the correct killer before it's too late. Each role is crucial to the town's survival. I've played twice in about 40 minutes, it's fast and super casual fun.

When I played online there was 15 people; 7 of which joined the game... so it was pretty fun. There is so much deceit good luck finding the killer!

Most negatives indicate a problem with popups. Maybe I haven't played enough but I haven't seen any. Just annoying login screen.

Worth $5, not my type of game but really fun!
